8Xq6SStlizrg24sGsFX-ng.text: Herefordshire snails and oxtail braised in stout with parsley breadcrumbs £8.25The appetisers arrived and it was a nice surprise seeing the 6 individual snails placed on what looks like mini egg-cups. Dig in and you scoop out the snail and oxtail which goes very nicely with the stout and parsley breadcrumbs. Next up was the scotch eggs. Please excuse my knife skills as I did not manage to slice it cleanly in half. Thin slice of venison coated in crumbs and fried, encasing a runny egg with the yolk oozing. No easy feat to get the venison crumbs crispy and crunchy with the egg still nicely cooked without turning rubbery. The venison by itself is quite salty but balances out with the creaminess from the egg yolk This is definitely far nicer that what I was served in my work canteen. I actually did not feel good after eating the scotch egg at work. Having only discovered and eaten 3 scotch eggs in my life so far, I don't know if this is the Creme de la Creme but it is good. Grilled steak of Berkshire roe deer and Douglas fir sausage with raw celeriac, spelt flat bread and field mushrooms £17.75One thing I noted from The Ledbury is that Brett Graham knows his game and does it well. If you want to know how a more unusual meat like roe deer should be cooked and taste like, this would be the place to try and it certainly doesn't disappoint.

xN27pfXm5fc-jbrSwoeazw.text: The hype, the HYPE!!!  Gettin me all out of my area to go to the ONLY michelin-starred gastropub in London to see why it's blowin up as it is....The food is lovely - let's not deny that.  My beef cheeks with mash and onion rings were luscious and fell apart at the touch of a fork.  Other highlights included the butternut squash soup and brown-prawns on toast, the coffee ice cream, and one of the specials of the night...veal schnitzel.  But honestly, it's not like I haven't had this same type of homestyle, traditional British fare before.  Although the prices are pretty great for this type of establishment (£68 with wine), I would prefer to go to Odette's and savor the slightly different tastes and textures they have to offer.What sets HA apart though, is their BREAD SATCHEL.  That's right.  I had no shame to ask for two satchels.  The white bread tasted like the best french baguette's fluffy/chewy inside wrapped in a thin croissant crust and then slathered with delicious butter.  Oh my christ....   It is lunch time.

VPRtuCz2XTof4J2Fdmhv3A.text: This place was amazing.  I had one of the best food experiences of my life here.  The first time I went here, I stumbled in lost looking for food with a friend after being pointed out to this place by a local.  They were booked, but some amazing hostess invites us to the bar where we were given a Scotch egg (wrapped with cured venison) and a bottle of Old Speckled Hen.  I was HOOKED.  Damn that egg was amazing.We got reservations for that weekend.  We had more eggs obviously, and a feast that included pigeon and venison shoulder... and everything was delicious.  It was euphoria, I was in heaven.I definitely recommend getting reservations early.

dni9Ck64YLRzJUnrKlzyJw.text: Herefordshire snails and oxtail braised in stout with parsley breadcrumbs £8.25 The appetisers arrived and it was a nice surprise seeing the 6 individual snails placed on what looks like mini egg-cups. To read the complete review, please go tochopstix2steaknives.blog…

5vI-aRohsvCI5gnmSR9zvg.text: This place deserves it's Michelin star. Simple as that. It's a pub (kind of) that does fantastic food. I've actually been several times and dind at this place. One time it was particualarly disappointing (the service not the food) but I was assured that this was a one off. My resulting comlaint got us a tasting menu which did a lot to restore my faith in this place. The Harwood Arms does a variety of good English food and specialising in game. You are alost always guaranteed to see at least one of Pidgeon, Pheasant, Venison or Grouse on the menu, as well as traditional lamb and beef. You can also get proper English ales, in old schoo pint pots and the wine list is good too. If you get chance (i.e. if it's on the menu) then try the Scotch egg. The yoke is still runny inside! They boil the egg (for 5 mins) and then put it on ice. it is then wrapped in the prok meat and breadcrubed, before being put in the oven. hence when it is cooked it is still soft. Delicous!  I recommend this place. It is reasonably priced and the food is excellent. You might have to book well in advance, but it's woth it.

w_I7Kok_z5MC4zdaIDq9bQ.text: after having eaten pretty vegetarian for the last week, i went seriously carnivore last night.  this was one of the better meals i've had in london.  three of us came for dinner last night, and it was great.  this place is kind of hard to find if you don't know the area, but luckily we took a cab, b/c it's in the middle of a residential area.for apps, we tried the special of a poached duck egg over chanterelles and bacon as well as the snails w/ braised oxtail and bone marrow.  the snails were DELICIOUS, and they fit a ton of braised oxtail into each shell.for my entree, i had the roasted cod over potato puree, leeks, cauliflower, and fried mussels.  i also tried my friend's braised beef and my other friend's venison, and all of it was fab.  the bread that comes to the table is also yummy.finally, for dessert, we got the donuts filled w/ fig jam, rolled in ginger sugar, w/ a side of sour cream to share.  omg, to die for.if you're looking for a meaty, adventurous meal, this is the place to go.

cNUTzaqLva5M2rhrLdK69A.text: This lost a star only cause we came here on a monday expecting to get a table.. Needless to say this must be a popular venue (being the only michelin starred pub). Lovely warm pub atmosphere. The staff werent as friendly as i thought and seemed to not be that on the ball. Tasty starter and standard drink prices. I will update this review once ive been back for a meal :)

HzCkIdGeCYoEHNVo74Dpew.text: Had snail and deer haunch. Both were very good or excellent!

1Lt_I2rypy5JO3YBzKMC1A.text: What a delicious and inviting place.The decor was simple and clean, yet cozy and well-lit, in the vein but a step up from the average gastropub.The food was scrumptious and well-priced. We each tried the snails with osso buco marrow bone (an odd combo but it works), and the bread, both a plain (sourdough?) and a pumpernickel were fresh and quite tasty.For mains, the three of us ordered a different dish and shared: mutton, pheasant, and beef cheeks. Though they were all delish, the mutton was a standout. Crispy top almost made it taste like pork belly. In a word, "yum."A rich meal, to be sure, so we all shared a portion of camp coffee ice cream. Unfussy and delicious.With wine for two of us, the total bill came to 97pounds. Not cheap, but certainly resoanable for the amount and quality of the food.

cCrAiRbNbPwn9HFjK4oXGw.text: The Harwood Arms is one of the top gastropubs in London at the moment.  The menu focuses on seasonal items and much of the meat is sourced from one of the partners who has hunting rights in the countryside.The scotch egg made with venison meat was a great way to begin the meal.  We also shared an order of kippers croquettes - which were very assertively flavored.The deer is a signature item.  We had the Muntjac deer for two with came with all the accompaniments we needed.  The meat was both sliced and on the bone.  This deer had real flavor and tasted far superior to farmed meat.Puddings: Bowl of warm lemon curd and sherbet doughnuts with whipped cream and heather honey.  We left stuffed.  Reservations recommended.  It is only a short walk from the tube station.  Service was quite welcoming.

NhbLvaV5xA3PV_zHLhxE-Q.text: I really want to give the Harwood Arms 5 stars, because the food was superb.  However, the service was almost laughably slow near the end of our meal, and we basically felt ignored by the staff, who could not be flagged down to bring us the bill.  Thus, 4 stars.Now, back to the food.  It really couldn't have been any yummier.  The game was excellent and beautifully cooked, and I enjoyed the nicest bowl of soup that I've had in recent memory.  Also, it's worth mentioning that the wines by the glass are very reasonably priced and genuinely interesting.  I feel like often a glass of wine by the glass is pretty unremarkable, but both the white and the red were delicious and unusual.  An exceptional dinner, and I feel lucky that we live close enough to walk home at the end of the night.  I think they need an extra server though, because we really did feel ignored by the wait-staff.

vOmZ-f183JXuJlOMNhRpig.text: Booked a table for a special occasion for this evening 2 months ago & they have no record of it.They told me they are fully booked and I have no proof! Handled terribly. How'd they get a michelin star?

S7fZGcdz9Le5HQ-SE7D-DQ.text: Pleasant venue, nicely cooked food, good service. A nice gastropub. recommended

6uzKNHcyXwvWNiVHWn3lsw.text: I'll preface by saying that this place is a HIKE from where I am in Angel--nearly an hour's journey. And yet, it was worth it.While I can't speak to whether this place "deserves" a Michelin star--I've seen other pubs that deliver on a similar level and lack one--the value proposition here is compelling. The food is uniformly excellent and very reasonably priced--especially for west London. From the Scotch Egg (worthy of its reputation) through to a simply diabolically delicious cod main, this place delivered high quality at reasonable cost. Add in a surprisingly authentic-feeling pub atmosphere and you've got quite a package. If I lived anywhere near here, I'd be a regular.

6N2YoWvxNk0byA1ROQs3MA.text: The Harwood Arms is much more than just another gastropub. Chef Stevie Williams cooked at two Michelin star The Square, so this is not the kind of pub food that involves heating things up in a microwave. A key reason why the food is so very good here is the produce, the game being supplied by sister restaurant The Pot Kiln in Berkshire, whose owner is a keen hunter. Consequently the venison, wild rabbit, pigeons etc that appear on the menu at the Harwood Arms are not from some mass-produced source, but from a real enthusiast who knows how to handle meat. Crayfish from the stream outside the Pot Kiln also regularly appear at the Harwood Arms. The kitchen also shows strong technical skills. Its regular dessert of delicious beignets show the skills that the chef picked up at The Square, while the Hardwood's Scotch egg is the stuff of legend in foodie circles. Made with venison rather than pork, each one made to order with a soft-cooked egg nestling inside the warm casing of meat and carefully seasoned batter, this is a great deal more than a bar snack. Several other serious places now offer a version, a sincere form of flattery and yet the Harwood Arms version is still the best I have eaten. The menu changes regularly but any game dish is a safe bet - there is even a complete vegetarian menu for those preferring their bunnies to be fluffy and cute rather than tasty. I have been extolling the delights of the Harwood Arms since it opened, and it now has a Michelin star as recognition of the skills on show here. See andyhayler.com for additional details and photos.

pWcQpv09WGWsvMFvDzMPpQ.text: Another leading light in London's burgeoning gastropub scene, The Harwood was never likely to live up to its hype. That it came damn close though speaks volumes. Shall we get the niggles out of the way? A side dish of kale never appeared. The much-touted venison scotch egg was a twist for the sake of a twist. When two vaguely professional foodies and the owner of a restaurant that celebrates British food wouldn't have known it was venison without reading the menu, it's probably time to go back to sausagemeat, chaps. A sea bream dish that was bright and light but came with pointless - and alarmingly bland - squid. A charming mini doughnut pudding that was disappointingly light on the jam. However, kipper croquettes were among the best bar snacks I've ever had. The snails were exemplary. The crispy brawn on the British meat platter deserved a starter of its own built around it. And the shoulder of roebuck, with celeriac mash, was probably the best piece of meat I've ever had in a pub. Topped with maple cured bacon and mustard, it was sweet, punchy, rich, tender It's a good job screens are wipe clean as I'm drooling just reminiscing. The celeriac and pickled mushroom salad that also came with it was also a perfect foil. Blooming good wine recommendation too - Rully, Meix Guillaume according to the notes, with deep blackcurranty notes to set the venison off. Smashing. When it's good, the Harwood Arms is spectacularly good. When it's bad well, it's probably still better than 90% of gastropubs in London.

rKPVOB-z1hIk7ZhZQjS_lA.text: The service was amazing. Right after we ordered the waitress told us about the Scottish eggs, which I had never heard of and now I can't stop thinking about them. I ordered the Sunday dinner and I was a little disappointed, because I was told that it was the best place to have it. Overall I'm glad I went there although I wish I had chosen a different restaurant for my Sunday dinner, and I wish they had Pepsi.

VXlhMvueG5Ee7d6nH_gbNw.text: Quite possibly the best pub food I have ever had! Highly recommended but make sure you book!

kgcklidjml-YWpmmXWztvg.text: They hunt their own game and bring it to your table. I think that the shoulder of venison - smokey, rich and creamy - slow cooked until it pulls apart like butter - is phenomenal... they say it's big enough for 4 (which is true) but I was so gobsmacked by it that I polished off half of it myself. Their menu is inventive and full of interesting combinations. This is also the place to get a gourmet Scotch Egg, which I thought was an oxymoron until I tried it. Parking is a bit prickly - with odd restrictions and the exodus from Chelsea stadium - so a taxi or tube might be best. Ambiance is okay but not fantastic. This is a 'working' pub alongside its gastro endeavours, so it feels a bit eclectic. I wish they did a bit more with the decor but otherwise it's a very nice surprise in an otherwise unremarkable location.

jnLaNpv3VD6SC9I93XqlNQ.text: Mid week lunch - great value, great food. Pity its all the way in Fulham.

G6sO5Ya6eB3WJh7sK9W4wg.text: this was the best restaurant I tried in the UK. despite having 1 michelin star, prices were very reasonable. everything we had was amazing. their version of scotch egg is good, but does not have sausage wrapped around the egg (still quite tasty, however). all the meats were well prepared and high quality. a bit out of the way from center of london, but worth the trip. service when we went was a bit poor, but i attribute that to some confusion over which waiter owned our table... we sat ignored for a good 30 minutes before anybody came by to deliver our drinks and take our order, despite our attempts to flag people down. we had to actually get up and tap somebody on the shoulder.

JG3sP3Kss6Dz6a3iNSc_mQ.text: Fantastic high end hipster take on the traditional English pub. We had an incredible scotch egg (soft boiled, wrapped in crumbed black pudding) and the night's special - braised venison with an unforgettable smoked onion tart. Excellent service. Highly recommended.

Bx9xEJ0j6pMTOoBfHc_Hng.text: Made a reservation for dinner and was given 6.15 pm time, but when we arrived they seemed to still be setting up menus for the evening.  There was quite a delay between us being shown to our table and someone taking our order, however when the food did come it was very good.  I didn't want any appetizers from the menu but had heard about their famous Scotch eggs (on the bar menu) and they were happy to accommodate my request.  The Scotch egg was excellent!Their bread is great and everything we ate was good.  The atmosphere is quite casual and typical of a London pub.Their online booking system explains you only have your table for two hours (unless you request it for longer at the time of booking) so that was my concern with them not being ready when we arrived at our reserved time - we didn't want to run out of time to complete our meal :-)

TvRAYPcD-GsjRK0PUy_yXg.text: This place was a bit out of the usual touristy areas. It reminded me of cambridge (massachusetts) if London were like a Boston.  The area was super cute and when we got out of the tube stop, there was a map there that actually let us know where the restaurant was (we did write down directions to walk it since the usual touristy maps don't go this far out!).  Everything we had here was awesome.  The way the do meats is excellent.  There wasn't anything that we had that we didn't love.  We also checked out St. John while we were in London (very similar to Harwood Arms) and we both enjoyed Harwood Arms more.

qPR4OQAEFw6mq6c6erVMwQ.text: Went here last week for Sunday roast. MAN is it punchy! BUT, we had an incredible meal and I'll definitely go back for a special occasion.I was immediately taken by this place. It's hidden within a load of houses, like a little gem :) The big wooden tables, eggshell blue paint and quirky decor looks like the inside of Elle Decoration, and we were greeted with smiles.We booked the same day and bagged a table at 3.45pm (they stop serving lunch at 4pm) - late sure, but hey, it was Sunday. We ended up getting beef rib to share for £45, but it was huge and we ended up taking some home. The yorkshires and roast potatoes were great - as was the veg. Plus, the house wine (which I always get because a restauranteur friend of mine said that places always get judged on their house, so it's good to go for).We'll be back!

UomxjH-4AyCSGFKt4KcICg.text: Positively amazing food!  a little bit hard to find but worth looking for.  Definitely make a reservation.   All dishes well conceived and perfectly executed -- well balanced in terms of both flavor AND texture.  Sometimes Michelin gets it right.

JBlT_RM5Py0o0uWfXCGUOQ.text: I must admit that I had my doubts. It was raining outside and I was about to embark upon a round trip of nearly 2 hours for Sunday lunch in a pub. It would seem a little crazy if the destination was not the Harwood Arms, famous for being the only 1 star pub in town and for its legendary scotch eggs. Despite my doubts, the rain was braved and some time later a slightly damp Duncan & Hannah W arrived at the pub. However, as I have already alluded, this is not a standard pub. Consequently, the bar doesn't really exist in a meaningful sense and if you arrived without a reservation you will be lucky to find a seat. The room however was delightful. Sunshine flowed in through large windows and a glass roof onto simple wooden tables dotted around the room. A happy hubbub of chatter filled the air. I had a pint of Otter to start (which was well kept and served in a mug) before moving onto the wine list. Aside from suggesting that diners should commit infanticide (and spending £1200) by ordering a 2005 DRC, the list was well put together and reasonably priced. We opted for a 2009 Morgan which was delicious. After we were seated the first thing to arrive was the bread, served slightly warm and thickly sliced. Whether homemade or not, it was a success and disappeared within seconds to make way for our starters, a winter salad of turnip, beetroot and deep fried quail's egg and a vicar's game pie. Both were delightful, marrying the strong flavours of game/egg with acidity and bite in the accompaniments.For mains, we shared a roast rib of beef with all the trimmings. This was not your standard Sunday lunch. First, it was served on a giant wooden platter, like something from a medieval fairy tale. Second, it featured slight variations and improvements on the 'standard Sunday lunch'. The beef featured slivers of smoked bone marrow, the greens came with a mustardy dressing and the Yorkshire puddings were filled with a mushroom and onion mixture. This kind of frippery can go two ways but it was all delicious and we loved it.We hardly had room for desert.  However, we pressed on regardless. A Rhubarb Eton Mess was a lovely mix of cream, crunch and rhubarby goodness.  However, it was the other desert which was the true star - custard 3 ways - first a ginger custard creme brûlée, second honeycomb ice-cream, third a custard cream biscuit.  All of these were great but the creme brûlée was simply stellar.  The custard was of a perfect consistency and the ginger provided welcome interest and texture.In short, this was a great meal.  I suspect that it might well be a better option for lunch rather than dinner.  However, I am sure that the food would be equally good whenever you visit.

KTJea7TqDCviCUVDAUeNGA.text: Such good food!!! I've been here twice and both times it has been amazing. Good specials and decent wine list. Not a single downside to this place.Pub quiz on a Tuesday as well! :)

2ongEiEm6MVLxpEqJrJHgA.text: What a fantastic meal. Fabulous friendly service, sophisticated yet humble food. Will remember for a long time.

eBwWhc2NiTXvThOy9x83WQ.text: Over the last 2 years the Harwood Arms has become a real go-to for meals for both business and pleasure and it deserves it celebrated 1* status. Some of the recent food highlights for me have been:Sea bream rissolesOyster fritters with lavabread mayoHare loin and faggot with roasted carrotHomemade bourbon biscuit and clementine ice cream sandwichThe wine list is smart, fairly priced and aside from that they are up for corkage.In fact the only difficulty (and I won't begrduge this to any restaurant) is that since they got their star booking is normally required. The Staff are nice and there's really not much more to it for me - excellent food, nice staff, good wines - what's not to like.

WRxJO4_w8F4Dlflx_RyqPg.text: Been in London a year now, and who knew the best meal i was to have had been waiting for me just down the street in Fulham...The food was innovative, fresh, perfectly executed, and fun. The head-to-tail pigeon starter embodies the contemporary and daring menu.

H6I62DCp5Jnpw9U_1WYrxg.text: Not being a fan of scotch eggs, I took a little convincing, but boy was it worth it!! I've come here a few times for drinks and love the cozy atmosphere. The food if also good (but you'd expect that from a Michelin * kitchen). Nice selection of beer and wine, and though the listing has a £££, it's actually not as expensive as you may think. I've been to more expensive and lesser places than this in west London.

Xf4Tvrf2_cQN6UFhjWEEew.text: The Harwood Arms completely changed my perception about British food. This place is a real local experience in itself, far from the touristy Piccadilly / Leicester scene, and worth the pilgrimage.  Everything was spectacular. Deserves a Michelin star.

kx7GOUL-p88PLsNejPFchA.text: Stick with the starters and bar snacks and you'll be happy.The mains can be hit-or-miss, and are always pricey at around £20/plate.  That's the only reason I'm not giving it 5 stars.In contrast, bar snacks are usually just £3-5 and are the best that you'll find at any pub, especially their famous venison scotch egg.  Starters are generously sized, beautifully presented, creative and delicious.  Plus they're normally just £7-10, so go out British tapas-style and you'll leave happy.Also a big thumbs up for serving the best range of cask ales of anywhere in the neighborhood.

yYnmURzg87wSgWAbpki1OA.text: 4 stars- Pretty easy walk from W. Brompton Station thru some neighborhood streets. Very very good soda bread and homemade butter. Appetizer was Venison Scotch Egg for 4 pounds which was excellent (seemed like it was deep fried batter, w/ venison wrapped around egg). 5 out of 5 stars. Main was a recommended pork chop which was a tad dry and wasn't epic. 4 out of 5. Two nice wines- a recommended white Rioja byRemírez de Ganuza Rioja Erre Punto Blanco (not sure which year) but it was very very good. The red was less thrilling; i tried 3 wines before finding a '10 Barbera d'Alba that I liked. As a note, all the red wines were ambient temp which during the summer was about 10* too high about 75* F). Place had nice vibe, pleasant service. Would recommend to a friend.

TzPb1eltxQl2C7iVNe1KEw.text: 5 stars! Amazing place, friendly stuff and awesome Sunday roast. Our beef roast was close to perfection if there is a  perfection ? ;-) great starters : scotch egg, snails with oxtail. ... and I just love their side dishes, cauliflower cheese - simple and so tasteful.

bXmMe9RaY17VqON4Px_2cA.text: OK, the food was awesome, the atmosphere was just right-nice but in a shabby chic kind of way.  The staff was kind and quick to recommend and answer our questions about the food.  Oh, and the bread selection at the beginning...rustic yet delicious.  We each ordered something a bit different but the ribs were out of this world and soooo much food-could be shared.  We had the grouse....because evidently, when grouse is on the menu in England, you must order it!  It is a bit rich and dense in flavor, but....when in England:-)  The wine and beer selection is amazing, they even featured wine from my home county! -That's Santa Cruz, CA!Highly recommend this place, it's worth the effort.

Tqe5uAJ5-UXwHKT9zZUpEA.text: Simply, this place is just disappointing. I visited London and decided to try some interesting restaurants during my trip. I am a fan of "gastropub" and using seasonal and fresh ingredients, so I was excited to try this pub after finding it online. I had very high expectations, especially after eating at numerous other sub-par London eateries. Unfortunately, the Harwood Arms was a complete let down. The décor is nice, and the ambiance is great, but the food doesn't live up to the hype. I had these cauliflower and cheese croquettes, which weren't actually anything more than fried cheese, and the scotch venison egg was heavily over salted. In fact, these two attributes turned out to be the themes for the night: fried and incompetently salted. The mains, a cod dish and a lamb dish continued this trend. The cod was so over salted that we had to peel off the top section for it to be edible, while the lamb tasted as if there was no salt at all. And the accompaniments to these mains were more fried items. It's a bit sad when the most enjoyable food on the table is the pickled cabbage.I understand that fried food is a big part of pub cuisine, but for a place calling itself a "gastropub" and having a Michelin star, I expected a little more finesse that just frying and salting things until I couldn't taste the ingredients anymore. What's the point of using great ingredients if they aren't cooked in a way to highlight their flavor?If you live in London, maybe this would be an interesting place to go to: it at least seems better than the other pubs I ate at. However, if you are from anywhere else, I would say skip it. You will just be disappointed. Maybe I am spoiled since I am from California and used to great ingredients at most restaurants, but I did not think that the Harwood Arms was anything very special, let alone worthy of a Michelin star or such hype.

F3FxnUYMq7_3EeDQ0djCBA.text: Wow.  Get the game board if they have it, but share.  It was incredible and delicious but way too much for one person.  The lamb neck stew was out of this world.  It was a little tricky to find, so plan accordingly.

XqVrBfl_dICniV-vsdNPnw.text: classy gastropub.  simply menu, modern british.  venison was tasty.  cod was tender.  garlic potatoes were perfectly seasoned and have a fun, crunchy texture.open space, rustic wood giving the warmth of home.quiz night is good...and even better if you know a bunch of trivia (useless but entertaining information).we docked 1 star because they don't have a good selection of beer.  however, they do have a nice wine list if you're a wine-o.

QsgcVnFKjxEpvF_6MF8QIA.text: A michelin starred gastro-pub in Fulham...sign me up! This quaint, bright and airy pub is located in the heart of a rather random residential area about a 10 minute walk from the Fulham-Broadway underground station. We stumbled upon it late on a Sunday afternoon (thanks Yelp!), and luckily they had a few cancellations and were able to accommodate us. Normally you have to book a few weeks in advance for Sunday roast.For starters, we shared the wild game platter. Instead of cured meats, the Harwood Arms offers spruced up versions of such British favourites as sausage rolls, venison scotch egg, grilled boar sausage, and liver parfait. It was perhaps the finest sausage roll I've ever had and the first time I've had one paired with a glass of Pol Roger. To finish the starter consisted of a wild game consommé.For the main, we shared the roast pork for 2. This large platter came with pork 3 ways---roast, pulled, and pork belly. The pork belly in particular was a standout and the most tender fall apart piece of pig I've had in some time. Definitely worth getting if on the menu. The portion for 2 was large and also came with some  charcoaled butter greens, roast potatoes, and chutney.The Harwood Arms is arguably one of the best pubs for food in all of London, and if you are a fan of wild game and who isn't these days, it's definitely worth making a booking!

tOc6ZlXUMa-oNGWxbLSg5g.text: Simply Awesome! Go here and feast!Located in the Fulham residental area, this unassuming pub can easily fool the eye. Looking like many of the pubs around, this is one of the few pubs to hold a Michelin Star. Came here on a Sunday, so appropriately so, a Sunday roast is required. They had 2 on the menu, one as part of the specials (Venison) and the standard one (Beef). Each of the roast are recommended for 2 people and with 4 in our group, we had to get both. Here's the rundown:Starters:BreadEat the Soda Bread. It's that damn good.Butternut squash soup with squid and garlicThis was amazing. It came in a small shot glass-like cups and was savory and succulent. Only wished there was more as it was a great instrument to cut through all the meats.Harwood Arms Scotch EggsNot on the menu during our visit, but we ordered it and you should too. I haven't had scotch eggs before so I couldn't compare against anything, but this was also quite good. Slicing through the egg allowed for the gooey beautiful yolk to ooze onto the outer meat layer. Roasts:BeefBeautiful pink center with an outer ring. Along with the beef's own jus, it was melt in your mouth goodness. VenisonThis was wrapped in bacon to keep the venison nice and moist. It also added a salty-sweetness to the game meat. Having the soup along with the venison was a great interplay to cut through the meat.Along with the huge pieces of meat come several accompaniments. All very good in their own as well.Accompaniments: Crispy Garlic PotatoesNice potatoes that served a nice textural difference. Not only that, they were darn good with the garlic essence and spices.Cheese CauliflowerA very flavorful and another addition to the cutting through the richness of the meat.Mushrooms & BeetsTwo separate sides, but both roasted and just simply good.This was a lot of food and I'm still missing several sides. You'll need to come extra hungry in order to be even close to finishing this behemoth of a meal. With that said, all the food was excellent and I would recommend everything above and anything else you can fit in your stomach. Absolutely amazing.

photos.caption: Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Roast of beef and venison. Crazy!

Gy-Clpm6fpPl3NnAcc-z4Q.text: Traveled almost an hour to get here, by bus and foot. Have to be dedicated to find it. Pleasant setting. Tables very close together. Seats in chairs need to be reupholstered.  Very little cushioning. Noise level extremely loud. Do not think you will be able to converse with table mate. Food was creative. Only fixed menu pricing. 33 or 39 pounds. Two or three courses. Starter was pigeon , venison, and pork sausage. Also had snails and mushrooms on toast. Nicely done. Second courses: pork chop( cut thin and nothing special. Other main course was lamb. Perfect. A much better choice. Dessert was fruit tart with ice cream. Again not as creative as first courses. When bill came, we had been overcharged for one drink.Service was prompt.

SR3BToTI4stIru8Z4F4Qyg.text: Hardwood Arms was an unexpected culinary surprise for me. We were on our honeymoon and my husband had wanted to try a gastropub and chose to go here. As soon as we entered the space i knew we were in for a treat. The decor was cozy and inviting. Our waiter helped us navigate through the menu and gave us his recommendations. Everything we ordered was delicious including the Cider they had on tap. My favorite by far was the exquisite game board. It was a flavor explosion; Even the consommé was outstanding. Also, the scotch egg and the mini fried potatoes are a must. The only disappointment was the dessert, I'd save myself the 10£ next time.

photos.caption: Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Scotch egg

h4jltdHRGKh6e9AetmESlg.text: I'm so lucky that this is just around the block from me.  They have the best pub food - if you can even call it that.  Definitely get a booking if you're trying to go Thursday-Saturday nights as they are always full.  But if you're just going for a drink - be sure to save room for their bar bites.  Get every one of them, and enjoy.  They're so reasonably priced for what you get, and their scotch eggs are the best!  And their potato finger things - divine!  I can't wait to go back for a Sunday roast!

Mk7vTfoDdNGRtV1pFWP2Zw.text: This place looks like the hundreds of traditional pubs from the outside. It just seems like a neighborhood bar. Then you realize their menu is not at all pub grub. It's a calm, cozy, rustic yet elegant restaurant. I had a birthday dinner here and my "host" who loves to splurge got plenty of food for the table. He was disappointed because he wanted to have the whole pig special, but they don't have it ready just for any day. Their regular menu was still delicious.The scotch eggs were amazing. For myself, I ordered the pork loin. It was perfectly cooked and the onions with it could have been a dish by themselves.Honestly, the most remarkable part of the meal was the vanilla donuts with lemon curd. I think I was required to share, but I wanted those birthday donuts all for meeee!

FLSQ1UCwtUeggpPqyT8ReQ.text: Cool staff and the food was delicious.  Pretty crowded so I'd recommend a reservation.  I had venison, partridge & scotch egg, all were good.Nice decor, the bar itself isn't very big, 2 seats and a small sitting area.  Pretty sure that they are constantly changing the menu.

IW1MeRZDXyx37hawcOiTjQ.text: The traditional London pub with some nice ales on cask, a good bar, a fireplace and a great kitchen seems to be becoming a rare elusive beast not easily spotted within the city. The problem seems to be that a lot of them have been bought up by the same 2-3 major corporations who use the same shit frozen pies and pre-packaged food. That is anything but the case here though, This has to be my favorite pub in all of London, and the Sunday roast is absolutely divine: Aged Rib Eye, perfectly medium rare, Bone marrow gravy, and the most perfect Yorkshire pudding. This was my 4th trip here and I have had the specials, and other mains as well all of which were just spectacular. they have never missed a step with impeccable service and divine food. Couple of tips, Make a reservation or get there early before food service and have a few drinks at the bar expecting to eat at the bar if you do not have a reservation. Also order the Scotch Egg (it is only on the bar menu but they serve it in the dining room too).

photos.caption: Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Seriously how do you soft boil it enough that you can peel it and then deep fry it without making it hard?

1FTfSaTjJ9Ol1a0hhASkfw.text: Excellent menu.  Our group of booksellers sat at a round table and it was one of my favorite meals in London during the London Book Fair for conversation and food.  It's not far from Olympia so a convenient location to the fair.

U9Lq6lBTTHQgxkSVAsGfZQ.text: I came with two friends to this Michelin star neighbourhood gem tucked amongst the residential houses near Earl's Court after one of them (from America) had heard about it back in the States. I've also seen on a list of top gastropubs in London, because if memory serves, it is the only one with a Michelin star. The restaurant was quite relaxed on a weekday evening, but even then nearly every table was full. They have a rotating seasonal menu with the option to order 2 courses for £33.50 or 3 courses for £39.50. And the night started off on a good note because before the meal, we got wonderfully soft fresh bread served with soft butter at room temperature (so many restaurants don't get this right!), sea salt, and a few slices of salami. I've never gotten complimentary cured meat before - so impressed! We also ordered a bottle of sauvignon blanc, which was quite reasonably priced at £26 (there are also a number of other sub-£30 options on the list).For starters, we ordered the pigeon faggots, the pressed pig's head, and the Cornish squid, and I got to try some of each. My choice was the squid, which came with a good 5-6 bite sized pieces, but the faggots were more like 3 small meatballs and the pig's head was actually a small fried chunk of meat that tasted a lot like a ham croquette. I thought the squid was well executed, but if you are going to be adventurous, the faggots were delicious and exceeded my expectations. By contrast, the pig's head was interesting but rather underwhelming when you expect something striking (the name sounds cool, right?) and you get something smaller than a hash brown. For mains we got wild mallard, pheasant, and beef cheek. My selection was the pheasant, which came recommended by our server when I was deciding between the mallard and the pheasant, and it was very tender and definitely a crowd pleaser (my two friends thought it was their favourite too). The mallard was a little overwhelmed by the beets it was served with, which dyed the whole dish purple, and the beef cheek was nice but tasted much like your typical beef.For dessert they had beer ice cream served with some sort of buttermilk cream. We were sufficiently intrigued to order it, but didn't come away all that impressed. I'd say that was my general takeaway from the restaurant as well... the menu had some interesting items on it and it's hit or miss with those, but if you come expecting a Michelin star establishment to sweep you off your feet, Harwood Arms falls a little bit short.

24EI4sxNmZtKn8Cur0POkA.text: Outstanding menu offering game, veal or lamb as mains with the choice to add a starter and/or desert.Wine list is remarkable and superbly managed inhouse by Alex and his team.Service by Ed was prompt, kind and very attentive.One of the best dining experiences I have had in a long time.

CdPRlxZBuL8YPNW_IOFN-A.text: One of the best meals I've ever had, anywhere (not just in London)My only regret is I've now been here twice and both times venison (which I'm told is their specialty) was not on the menu. Never mind: everything else was expertly prepared. From a perfectly chunky pig's head to a really nice pork tenderloin roast (actually the tenderloin, while very good, was the least interesting thing on the plate: the pork belly and cracklings were much better.) The truffle mash fell short only because it did not taste of truffle (this happens so often, why bother?) But a small criticism. The bread here is also some of the best I've ever tasted (which I think it really saying something coming from someone who's lived a lot of his life in San Francisco.)

WDMhDIhR3xWGI8kNGbGUuw.text: A completely exciting and different experience. We began with the artichoke soup and the pigeon faggot. The artichoke soup was disappointing in that I was yearning for artichoke that never seemed to come through. The pigeon faggot, on the other hand, was delicious and flavorful. We shared the saddle of venison and it was A HIT! I don't even want to give away the thrill of this plate, but you must order it if you join them. It is worth the whole trip. We finished with a guinness ice cream with buttermilk malt and the doughnuts. The ice cream was nothing to write home about, yet the doughnuts were warm and scrumptious. Harwood Arms is a MUST!

photos.caption: Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Donuts
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Saddle of venison

28-GcWFl9qqe1JCtdGGIOw.text: A proper gastropub! It took us more than an hour to drive to the place (crazy on a sunday when there was a Chelsea match on-going). But it definitely worth the trip.Ordered many items on the bar menu. Have to say every single dish delivered.Loved the place.

wS0Ub3zGvkdDC5azIOBehA.text: Just finished our meal at The Harwood Arms. This place is ridiculous! Amazing service (the manager, sensing I liked to cook, shared some of the preparation methods for items we enjoyed, and how to do it at home), and perfect cuisine. The bread was dangerous. The wine was paired perfectly. And the entree was cooked to perfection. World class cuisine nestled in the corner or a quiet London neighborhood. This is what good cooking ought to be like.

photos.caption: Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Roasted ribeye special with smoked bone marrow

PtHwtvkxs9QMYoAPv2banA.text: There is nothing quite like a proper gastropub.  Somewhere that is comfortable with a great menu and good booze. It sounds like a simple formula but sadly so many restaurants get it so wrong. The Harwood Arms, however, gets it so right. The menu is great.  You could go for the £25 set menu which sounded delicious, but we were tempted by sharing a few a la carte options. The duck terrine was a bit on the smallish sides but as they say it's not quantity but quality and this was a bit special.  Pheasant main course with buttered greens and potatoes was an outstanding use of seasonal produce cooked pretty perfectly. If you haven't tried pheasant before this is the place to do it.  And without sounding trite it does kinda taste like chicken... The staff were efficient if a little standoffish  but by the end of the lunch we had managed a smile from the typically stiff upper lipped British staff. This place is so quintessentially British that it would be somewhat rude to visit London and not check it out.

photos.caption: Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Pheasant with greens and potato, enjoy while in season and it's cold outside!
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Duck terrine with moreish brioche, tastes as good as it looks!

p6t3LTJeJAlsAoxlWqrAmw.text: The food here is fantastic. Try the scotch eggs to start with. My skate was cooked to perfection. Service needs some work but overall highly recommended.

photos.caption: Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom

OGEPD1rwUQXM2aA-KVEcSw.text: Truly one of the best meals I've had in England. The lamb was perfectly cooked and not gamey, the raspberry soufflé was awesome. Only complaint was sitting at the bar since I did not make reservations. Worth every pence

rha38g2iC0lML3vQsQSElQ.text: This place deserves it's Michelin Star. Location/Staff/Ambiance: Atmosphere is warm and there is nothing I love more than a pub in a residential area. I think the walk there prepared me for just the type of mood that is is. Warm, inviting and friendly people.Service was spot on. We had what seemed two wait staff serving us. Maybe they all just share tables? Not sure but they knew the food and drinks and were just the perfect level of not too talkative but had personality.the best part, the FOOD!:To start the homemade bread they serve is good enough you have to remind yourself that you have more food coming...delicious. There was this amazing two person dinner special which was venison with bacon, red pickled cabbage, half a butternut squash with some melt-in-your-mouth cream filling (not sure what?) and veg. We were in heaven. Desserts were also out of this world (hello doughnuts!!). I enjoyed the dessert with toasted marshmallows wow. That with a 10-year port to end the evening was perfect.We brought guests here on their first night in town and we just loved the experience. Not over the top, excellent at what they do and friendly. Will be back often.

UPrlRDrd0eTdHSqDga6Rsw.text: My boyfriend lives in west London and I live in east London. We're like Romeo and Juliet, or some shit. From different worlds etc, you know what i'm saying. We mostly eat out east, obviously. But I am making an effort to find great food places in the west. I get out my Yelpy app and discovered the 'best Scotch egg' in London is right in his neighbourhood. Gotta get me some of that. We trekked up a very residential back street to find the lovely and very hip Harwood Arms. I remarked that it had a very 'east London vibe', this was met with a scowl. But it totally does. Great hardwood floors and design, cool tattooed bar staff* playing 'The Tallest Man on Earth' album. This is not your grandfather's local! We ordered a couple of beers and THE VENISON SCOTCH EGG and they were totally indulgent. It was warm and decadent - you cut through it and a perfectly cooked egg yolk runs out. The venison is rich and the sea salt on top is a great touch. I'd love to come back here for dinner, the daily menu looked amazing but pricey!*The difference is the bar staff in east London are just douchey-cool, which I hate.

tnkJ1ct4_sQgybR6WLUiwQ.text: Tested and approved yesterday night after a great dinner with my in-laws. Don't get fooled by the low-key pub-ish name, this is a proper 1 michelin star restaurant. 2 courses will cost you 33£, 3 courses 39£, and you really get what you pay for.Too much choice isn't necessary helpful, and I like the fact that the daily menu offer is limited. I went for the  "Buttered Cornish crab on English muffins with coastal herbs and pickled lemon" to start, as good as the name sounds :) Then for the "Rump of Herdwick lamb with creamed spinach, violet artichoke and roasted garlic", great combination of flavours. The meat was slightly under-cooked, but very qualitative.From the outside, Harwood Arms looks like your casual pub, but you'll find a more classic decor inside.Lovely restaurant in Fulham, for some quality business or family time.

photos.caption: Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Herdwick Lamb with creamed spinach
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Buttered Cornish Crab on english muffins.

koVJ3Em8NWrJLQXoB3ZGsw.text: We came here for the famous scotch eggs and weren't disappointed. I liked the casual and unpretentious atmosphere, friendly service staff and clean toilets. The scotch eggs were to die for. It's made of a blend of venison and sausage, centered with a soft boiled egg bursting with smooth runny yolk - nice twist on a classic.

photos.caption: Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom

iRy0KLG48EYpnBQAN8_RZg.text: It was 4 years ago when I first made a group booking for the Harwood arms... and I couldn't make it in the end.  In between all of that, there were so many places to try and just haven't gotten around to booking a reservation.. then thought it would be great to try somewhere new for our Valentine's day meal.  Since it fell on a Sunday, lunch was a much better option.It was in a really quiet residential location however when you walk in, it had a really nice vibe.  Comfortable/casual yet really nice atmosphere.  They had the 3 course menu or a 6 course special Valentine's day tasting menu.  We weren't that hungry so decided against the tasting menu.  None of the starters appealed to us but the special of the day - 55 day aged ribeye for two sounded perfect for a Sunday gastropub lunch.  It came with onion stuffed Yorkshire pudding, cheese risotto fritters, greens along with bone marrow gravy.  It was delicious and exactly what we were looking for.  We were so stuffed that we decided against dessert and finished off with coffee.  I thought we were obliged to have at least 2 courses but glad they charged us just for the mains.  Definitely a plus for service.

eb0VF0cEM655vqBhzDeMAQ.text: Best.  The deer is absolutely amazing - my most recent was the deer shoulder.  I've been here twice, roughly 3 years apart, and both were excellent.   Good beer and wine of course, but come for the rustic food executed perfectly.  Just really one of my favorite places.

IYp7pA04-Dpuu5e7p-F5qg.text: This place was delicious. The staff is wonderful and helpful (as tourists we weren't entirely familiar with all the menu items). We tried a variety of dishes but the real stars were the scotch eggs (off the bar menu) and the deer and lamb off the lunch menu. Perfect cook and flavor! Also, the rosemary gin and tonic was my favorite. Incredibly refreshing after a very savory meal.

photos.caption: Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. The deer was definitely the star of the menu!
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. The lamb was perfectly cooked.
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Best scotch eggs!

PeMbvXityHzy3BFK18z6GA.text: I went here only for the bar menu. I purposely came here at an off time around 3pm and I had no problem getting a seat at the bar. I don't know what they normally serve for lunch, but the bar menu items are excellent and we'll worth the money and trip out to Fulham from central London.Harwood scotch egg- I essentially came here for this and it didn't disappoint. Crunchy on the outside, flavorful with a perfectly soft boiled egg.Venison rilletes- my favorite of the three items I ordered. Venison cooked on a stick of some sort (maybe fruit wood?), caramelized, and served with a delicious honey mustard sauce, and mustard-enhanced pickles. Cauliflower cheese croquettes. Very well done. Not as interesting as the first two (but difficult to be surprising as a croquette) but I enjoyed them, have no complaints, and would still recommend them if you're in the mood for it.

photos.caption: Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Split open Harwood scotch egg. An excellent investment of 5.
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Harwood scotch egg before being demolished.
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Cauliflower cheese croquettes on the left. Venison rilletes (my favorite!) on the right with a dipping sauce and pickles.

x6dtijhDDPwr7zac1_RvTQ.text: Sunday roast dinner of Herdwick lamb, cooked to utter perfection. Yorkshire pudding, duck fat roast potatoes, greens, parsnips, cauliflower cheese croquettes and gravy. Wow. And don't forget the scotch egg. Never thought 'pub' fare could be so exquisite; this is a must-try.

photos.caption: Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Sunday roast of Herdwick lamb, cooked to medium rare perfection

cWYYboJljxlWf7c-Wz7jiw.text: We all loved this place! While visiting family in London we all agreed that a traditional Sunday Roast had to be in order, and we found the Harwood arms based on yelp reviews. The food was DELICIOUS. The wine was really good, and the server was super fun and help. His scottishness fit right into the restaurant ambiance. Definitely go for anything here that they describe as "the roast", though probably stay clear of the fish. The fish was good, but looked horribly disappointing next to the giant meat and potatoes plate that we ordered. Enjoy!

photos.caption: Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Sunday roast rib eye

cN2tQKQkz-VrcPk8N9sziw.text: Although it takes a while to get to, as there is not much else around it other than homes, it is definelty worth it!!We had a lunch menu (starter, main, dessert), which was delicious.This is the only gastropub in London that has a Michelin star, however they do not boast about it, as they are very down to earth. The staff is very friendly and knowledgeable, and if you need any advice on what to drink with  your meal they are more than happy to help! I had the most delicious warm smoked salmon I have had in my life, which hoenstly melted lke butter in my mouth. The fact that I am not a huge fan of mashed potatoes completely changed as I also had the best mashed potatoes that I have ever had, it was truely life changing!! Creamy and buttery, I had to steal from the rest of my family members as I had finished mine! The dessert was the only point that dissapointed, as we had fried doughnut holes with some sort of cream, but they were extremely dry and tasteless, but we did not let that even influence our experience there!

vRnHsmZxmZ6LT57Q7yH1Dw.text: All love for London's only Michelin starred pub! WOOOO!!! Absolutely loved this place, great food, great vibe and service. The bread is unreal! as is the duck actually... we were 7 and tried LOADS of food, and were not disappointed. Missing star for the stifling heat in the place and the kind of slow service. Otherwise, absolutely exceptional pub food!

Cg8qShFyXrZVTVkGt5BWfA.text: We had read that this would be the place with the scotch egg that would change our lives, so we decided to make the trek out here for lunch.  It was pretty empty when we arrived, but they filled up, so making a reservation is a good idea.Special small plates to share: - Cauliflower cheese croquette: good with extra salt. 3 for £3.50 was pretty reasonable, and it came with bread and butter pickles - Scotch egg: perfectly soft cooked inside. The venison wasn't gamey at all.- Bread: dense inside, crusty outside, served warm. The butter and flaked salt are really good with it.They did a 2 course for  £35.50, and there was a special one for around £22.  We ended up sharing everything - Oxtail broth with suet pudding and pearl barley. The broth was light, and the dumpling was beefy. The texture on the dough was really good. - Charred Cornish mackerel: good char flavor. The grapefruit and fennel slaw underneath was light and a gold complement - Salt cod: I liked the seaweed type lettuce and sea beans. The cod was tender, and there were potato dumplings (like gnocchi)- Cornish sea bream: bacony creamy potatoes underneath were the highlight for me - Duck: perfectly pink duck breast with violet artichokes, kale (black cabbage), and chanterelles - Crispy layered potatoes: these came complimentary and were really good eaten warm with some extra saltSparkling and still water are complimentary.It was a bit of a slower lunch, but it was very leisurely, and food was solid.  I thought the croquettes and the scotch egg were the highlights. Service is very friendly, and it's a low key, brightly lit place with some touches of a British pub (the stuffed animals on the all, etc). It's very refined British food ,and it's worth checking out.

qkGLbxMAOy8XvSvW4Jo7mQ.text: First impressions: the interior is airy and bright but still has the traditional British pub feel. The bar itself is stocked with all my favorite gins and doesn't serve the horrible tonic, fever tree or nothing. Also the bread is incredible! To the food: it should be noted that we waited for almost an hour to be served and when it finally did arrive it was a bit cold. We ordered the Sunday roast beef ribeye, with all the trimmings. The meat was delicious, perfectly cooked and needed no gravy or additions. The cauliflower cheese was undercooked but tastey. The greens were over salted but cooked well and not soggy. The potatoes should have been roasted but were simply deep fried, which isn't the proper way. The Yorkshire pudding was perfect, and stuffed with beef and onions- a real treat. The dessert! Oh the dessert! Lovely!! Treacle ice cream with chocolate and stout, and buttermilk pudding with strawberries and amazing sorbet. To die for.The service staff were attentive and pleasant, although no apologies for the cold or long wait for food.Overall, I'm not sure if this place deserves a Michelin star... But I did enjoy it and the price was very reasonable without wine.

photos.caption: Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Treacle ice cream
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Buttermilk pudding
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Venison scotch egg

VGKlkxzMmDdDdeaVxGW9ZA.text: I've dined here several times.The atmosphere is wonderful and a true hearty British pub set in the beautiful South west area, allowing you to escape from the hustle and bustle of central London.The service is always pleasant, although I feel the menus and information by the waiters on dishes could be more detailed. E.g.) I ordered a rabbit salad starter and it came out in fried breadcrumbs...had I known it was prepared like this,  I wouldn't have ordered this dish.

DdTHfxgfgAzvVuke5NoDsA.text: A Michelin starred gastro-pub?  Is that really you? Greg discovered The Harwood Arms after doing research on best interpretation of gastro-pub food.  Is it no surprise that we found this place? Yeah, I didn't think so either.  I really enjoyed the neighborhood walk from the Fulham tube stop, and especially enjoyed the comforting, feels-like-home environment once you walked in.  For a Monday evening, there was certainly a lot of people that in for dinner, so we knew we were in the right place.We perused the menu, but let's be honest, the first thing we were going to order was the Venison Scotch Egg.  It came whole, which is a huge change from how I've typically had it where they cut it in half for you.  The awesome effect of cutting into this and seeing the beautiful inside is definitely a huge treat.  Not to mention, it was delicious, especially with that small add of salt on top!We were served two types of bread, one that was made of potato and the other made out of soda.  And in a typical overexcitement, we overindulged by eating too much of it early on.  But it was so delicious! Props to Harwood Arms for crafting their own bread too.We passed on appetizers, mostly because we wanted the mushroom tart but was informed it had sold out for the evening.  We did, however, add on a side of crispy garlic potatoes, which later on turned out to be a big mistake since we had overeaten on the bread.For our mains, I selected the leg and belly of Middlewhite pork with onions in ale and young carrots.  Greg had the roast Berkshire pheasant breast with buttered greens and a pressed potato side.  My pork was absolutely delicious, especially the pork belly.  The piece was portioned perfectly, and was just slightly crispy!  It might be some of the best pork belly I've ever had.  I struggled to finish my dish because I was trying to fend off the full feeling from the bread and the potatoes, but it was absolutely delicious.  Greg really enjoyed his pheasant but was also struggling to finish as a result of overindulgence in the starters.  We were both so full from dinner, but seeing how The Harwood Arms is known for their desserts, we really couldn't pass it up.Finally, dessert.  Yum!  We went with the special of the day, which was spiced cinnamon and apple ice cream with a caramel sauce and apple bits in addition to frozen goats' curd with vanilla, walnuts & figs based on a recommendation from the server.  My favorite?  The frozen goats' curd hands down.  This was creamy and light, and went well with my cappuccino!Overall, definitely a 5 out of 5 for The Harwood Arms.  Not only do they locally source their meats and veg, but they care so much about each of their dishes. Absolutely stunning meal in Fulham!

photos.caption: Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Frozen goats' curd
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Frozen goats' curd
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Cinnamon and apple ice cream with a carmel sauce

sFKsR8ObdySpIsyKksvTPg.text: Looks are certainly deceiving when it comes to this place. While it took us a little while to find this restaurant hidden in a residential neighborhood, it was well worth the wait. The servers were very forgiving that we were late and lost. (Life without Internet is so hard). We sat down and decided on a bottle of prosecco to share, and it was so crisp with a light peach flavor.I appreciated the specials they had on the board, but the daily menu also had so many enticing rustic dishes. We forewent appetizers because we weren't that hungry and chose entrees and dessert instead. I got the roast rump of veal with garlic mashed potato, mushrooms and artichokes. The veal was cooked a perfect medium and the potatoes were soooooooo creamy and dreamy. My friend got the breaded lemon sole with broccoli, fennel and brown shrimp, which she loved as well. It's amazing how they've taken simple ingredients and elevated them. We were excited to try the desserts after our fantastic main courses. We split the English cheese plate and the tarragon sugar donuts with blood orange filling. The cheeses were fairly mild. We'd never had oatcakes and it wasn't as good as the bread we're used to eating cheese with. The donuts were kind of a let down; the flavors didn't work well for me. A bite of them with the tartness of the blood orange, the herbal flavor of the sugar, and the rich cream didn't quite come together.We were amazed by how affordable our delicious (Michelin) meal was. It was such a pleasant low-key fine dining experience, which is ideal. I wish there were more restaurants like this!

gtGMj-s2YU6TInQIQhJMLQ.text: As with much British fare, I was let down here. While plating (in some cases) was creative and appealing, the food fell short. I had the quail three ways and the lamb. My wife had the rabbit followed by the osso buco. The quail was fine but the pairings on the plate brought nothing to the dish. The lamb was tough and totally devoid of any lamb flavor. The rabbit was serviceable but plating was a bit sloppy. The osso buco was forgettable. The best part of the meal was the dessert. It was some sort of berry soufflé. For a 100 pound dinner (without wine or drinks), I expect a lot more. Not really sure how this place received a Michelin star. Wouldn't recommend.

P8QRN9kMhQRAtrtOey-iHg.text: We were lucky enough to snag a late reservation at the Harwood Arms last night. The whole experience was wonderful - even though they were very busy and apparently one waitperson down for the evening the staff were all lovely and very helpful.The food was incredible and very reasonably priced - if you can get a reservation you will not be disappointed.

photos.caption: Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. (L) Venison starter, scotch egg, wood pigeon starter, garlic + potato soup w poached egg, asparagus and lardo (all incredible!)
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. the veal

rNlleZEX1vwiHvHYHiFxyg.text: A hidden gem in the West Kensington/Earl's Court underground stations  area.  We stayed at Holiday Inn at North End Road and had a couple of rainy nights to have dinner close to our hotel. After looking through Yelp findings and reviews we decided to give this restaurant a try. A good 10 minutes walk from busy street into to the residential area was well worth it.Now to the restaurant itself. It is fairly small, probably a little less than 20 tables with pretty minimalistic ambience, but good attention to details that make the visit very comfortable. The whole dining area is operated by two very friendly people who share the waiter/bartender responsibilities.  But don't let that discourage you!The menu was really short, but there were very few items that I wouldn't be interested in. And the specials sounded exceptionally, but unfortunately I couldn't try those.  We have shared the chicken livers appetizer, my wife had the veal and I decided to go with lamb.  All food looked and tasted simply phenomenal. Modern presentations, all ingredients match well and cooked just right!This restaurant maybe a little on a costlier side, but I think the money were well spent I would visit this place again and recommend it to friends.

HRzOndWTKton1Tck8h6QQw.text: I'm not impressed. It's a lot of money and a lot of effort to find this place. The food was very good, but the service was appalling. I won't be back.Many reviewers have commented on how few servers seem to be working the restaurant. Many have commented that they had to flag down their server. Yet those reviewers have rated this place 4 and 5 stars. Given the price I'm paying, especially with a "service charge" added to the bill for our table of 4, I'm not at all satisfied with the experience. We were sat for 45 minutes before we got our first drink. Anything else we needed required getting up to go find the waitress because she wasn't going to find us. There are plenty of pubs where this is the norm. But they don't charge £180 for a dinner for four (we didn't have wine). The meal lasted 2 hours, but most of that time was delay waiting on the service.I shudder to think how much more money the restaurant owner would make if they hired enough staff to be attentive to their patrons. They could actually turn tables over quicker and sell more food and drink by checking in more often. When she asked us whether we wanted dessert, my thought genuinely was about how long it would take to get it. I didn't fancy another 45 minutes to do coffee and dessert--Michelin star or no. I told her no, thank you, and we would like the bill. She still didn't hear that and I had to flag her down and ask for the bill a second time. The food is outstanding but the experience is not worth it.

-_czceFNDFpQA2KZKa2D0g.text: Upon first sight, The Harwood Arms looks like any corner pub. You wouldn't guess it proudly holds a Michelin star. Simple, wooden interior and no tablecloths as expected. Surprisingly, there were plenty of empty tables and it seemed like they only have one seating in the evenings. Did that reflect in the availability and attention of the service staff? Not really. We still had to make faces and wave our hands to get the attention of the two staff running around.The menu is quite interesting and has a varied selection in each of the appetizer, mains and dessert sections. Excellent wine list, plenty of new world and local wines, and the staff know what they are talking about in their recommendations.Two course menu £33.50, Three course menu £39.50Hereford snails with oxtail, stout and parsley - 6 giant snails stuffed to the top of the shell with juicy snail, diced oxtail meat, parsley and toasted breadcrumbs which added a nice thin crusty layer. The side toast with creamy baked cheese was a nice addition but a bit strong to complement the snails.Braised Longhorn beef with black cabbage, white beetroot and smoked bone marrow - good god this was deliciously tender beef that fell apart on my fork. The sweet white beetroot was perfectly matched. I didn't see much of the bone marrow and instead it seemed to have been replaced with a spinach or kale.Buttermilk pudding with English berries and toasted almonds - essentially a softer vanilla panna cotta topped with large fresh blackberries and raspberries, a homemade raspberry sorbet which was as good as it gets, and two almond friands on the side which were quite moist and dense.A great experience worth trying once but very rich flavours and meaty, not something I would go back for regularly.

photos.caption: Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom

YPQieRhHtOkSiWVk-mCruA.text: Had an amazing meal here with the gf.Everything about this meal was great: the decor, the ambiance, the service and, most importantly, the food.This place is a gastropub but upscale.   Warm and inviting with the wood floors and table tops but bright walls and good lighting to add elegance.   The beer list is to the point and insanely well priced.   The wine list had some great options at a decent value.We started with some champagne and a venison scotch egg.For my meal I had the lamb sweetbreads, the deer with roasted pumpkin and the English cheese course while the gf had the dressed crab, the partridge and the tart jam filled donuts.   Every dish was perfectly executed.   The cook on the deer was a perfect mid rare.   The partridge May have been the best thing with the bacon and cream kale.  This place has certainly earned their Michelin Star.   Well worth the price of admission.   Would definitely go back.

M24fhZGR9v58KJYNgiWZRA.text: We got a reservation here through a friend who works at the pub and went on a weeknight.The pub itself is beautiful and the service fantastic.The food was delicious, every dish we tried (and we were a group of around 8 people) was fantastic. It is pricey and the portions aren't exactly gigantic, but I do think the price reflects the quality of the food and the appealing setting. I would recommend the lemon curd donuts with earl grey cream. Would I go again: Yes

cbBxODi3IgrwgFGyUEGjOA.text: After seeing that this was the only pub in London with a Michelin Star, I HAD to try it out. And boy was I glad! The food was AMAZING. But, disclaimer: I don't think you can truly classify it as a "pub"- it has a way more upscale feel to it than normal English pubs, and a way more elaborate menu than you'd find at normal ones. Nevertheless, it was amazing. We started off with the crab tarts and the partridge with salad. Both were soooo good. The crab tarts had a small hint of lemon and it was the perfect flavor combination. The partridge was perfectly crisp on the outside and juicy on the inside, and the dressing of the salad was delicious. We then opted for the special of the day which was a braised deer shoulder with cabbage, parsnips, smoked bone marrow tart, and crispy potatoes. It was incredible!!!! The deer shoulder was wrapped in bacon and was soooo tender and delicious. Everything was cooked to perfection.Finally, we had the lemon donuts with an earl grey cream- also incredible. I highly recommend making a stop here, you won't regret it!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. The lemon donuts with earl grey cream. So yummy
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. The special of the day- braised deer
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Partridge with salad. Amazing

BdJgKSAzalNuD0bJeP71Vw.text: The best dinner I had in London, maybe in the world. The food is amazing - prepared and served to perfection, and the staff is attentive and help you to enjoy your food comfortably. No uptightness or pretentiousness you find in some high end restaurants. Highly recommended!

9VoyzxDANkSJYuvcm850cw.text: Everyone should fly to London and dine here. It's the only Michelin star pub in London. Get the Sunday roast. Amazing. Perfectly cooked meat. THE crispiest potatoes. Very flavorful Yorkshire. We also tried the crab and scotch egg. First time eating a scotch egg and it was underwhelming.

6GleN3kZVDB3PJ9KvwpMxg.text: Had a delicious dinner there for our honeymoon celebration! It was our first meal visiting England and everything was perfect! They surprised us with a celebratory dessert and glass of champagne, which was very thoughtful!

xqMx9K-hzh4hJZNxKjYTEQ.text: It's hard to find the right balance between comfortable yet exciting food, but Hardwood Arms does it. Nothing pretentious about the food or the place, yet it manages to be both elegant and comfortable at the same time. They deserve their Michelin star!

hgFbRFHTp3JHMAY-nnjC6Q.text: The Harwood Arms is the only Michelin-starred pub in London. You might even say that it's quite the gastronomic gastropub. Har har! Just make sure you're down to eat some game while dining here, since that is what they're best known for. 2 courses for £37.50; 3 for £46. While you're at it, grab a scotch egg to start.

inEZg47yYkQ5VjvnIA_Y_g.text: Thought this place was amazing, food was really good and service was impeccable.  The atmosphere was both lively and relaxed.  I'll be back next time in the neighborhood.

_PvbnmNcjcsgTsQvp9oFZQ.text: An old favorite! I know I have stated the bread was great here but I will say it again. I LOVE their Irish soda bread. The crust is crisp and the interior is soft and crumbly. A spread of butter makes it heavenly but it could be great plain too.After eating here so many times I am not sure why I just noticed that they have a rooftop garden! Butternut squashes were growing right above us and clearly visible through the skylight. If you haven't tried this place, do so soon!

9ohupvvFltHd_JoGkdjxwg.text: Great gastropub. I'd heard about their Michelin star, but it's not at all what you normally get in such places. It looks very casual more of a pub than a dining room and although the food was delicious and creative it's definitely more traditional than most other Michelin starred restaurants I've been to.Great wine list, divided by country which I like. Got a Spanish crianza 2012 called manium I think, which was nice.I tried a bit of everything, from the beetroot starter which was great to the special crispy rabbit which had a lovely sauce. We also got the special main which was deer for 2 with a 3 pound supplement each. I really enjoyed it. Just gamey enough, very tender and with some lovely vegetables, bone marrow tarts and gravy. Their chips are a highlight.To finish we shared the donuts because I can never say no to donuts. They were freshly made and not sweet at all which was very welcome after the feast.We definitely should only have ordered 1 starter as I was uncomfortably full for about and hour after we left - but that's just my friends and I being greedy piglets. My only complaint is that it's sooooooo far. I never come to Fulham Broadway and made the journey especially for the restaurant but being used to going to Clerkenwell, shoreditch or Islington or dinner.. it's unlikely I'll return soon.Total bill for 3 came to 185 with service so not too bad at all for the quality of the food!

Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Scotch egg. The best I've ever had

AeubVyOxeDkFtjbZ1jSvOg.text: 4.5 rounded up. The restaurant is known for their high quality, fresh game meat. I guess you can say they've got their game on.  ;)With reservations made a month in advance, two weeks out being sufficient, we headed to Fulham on a lazy afternoon for a late lunch.Our plan: Eat, drink and be merry!The location was hidden down the neighborhood's back streets, a charming walk leading to the pub/restaurant. It was easy to get to using public transportation.Once arrived, we were greeted by Assistant Manager, Sarah Marouane and seated quickly. The rustic vibe was certainly there and the fine details and linens elevated it to something more.We opted to order one set meal from the lunch menu and the blackboard special. Lucky me! There was only one order of the special left.The food was prepared with much detail and care. Every bite balanced in taste and texture. You can visually tell Chef Alex Sergeant and team treated every ingredient with care.Despite being over overzealous about trying the blackboard specials, I was disappointed in the aged meat. It was slightly underwhelming in taste. Perhaps the top players were every dish, I had to pick a least favorite.The service was thoughtful and besides the delay in our appetizers, they have their "game" together 100%. More on my website.What You Need To Know:-- Reservations can be made via Opentable-- Book at least two weeks in advance-- Public Transport: The pub is a 5 minute walk from all bus stops and tube station at Fulham Broadway.-- Travelcard Zone 2.-- Walking down a neighborhood street-- Dessert is also a winner!
