Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Puree of potato

dEqEdRwP8CDXHifhJuVhcg.text: This is my go-to place in London for Sunday dinner when I'm in town!  It's literally a Michelin-starred gastropub (the only in London)... but is super down-to-earth and casual.  There was even a dog at the table next to us.Harwood Arms' service is unassuming and friendly.  The food is AMAZING!  Don't miss the Scotch egg and the Sunday Roast which comes with beautiful vegetables, Yorkshire pudding, and perfectly crispy potatoes. The Irish soda bread is unreal.  They also have a great wine list with diverse offerings from across Europe.  What a treat!

h7491enOjq8vDhzqPayG1w.text: We stumbled upon the Harwood Arms and were blown away. A huge wine selection (we'd never heard of "orange" wine and were offered a taste-interesting but not for us). However, every morsel of food was amazing--from the bread to the cheese and onion tart, pot roasted guinea fowl, Cornish pollock, perfectly done vegetables to the raspberry Pavlova and lemon curd-filled doughnuts. The ambience was lovely with sun streaming in, Cape Buffalo and stags heads on the walls. Service was exemplary.

HmjgyRQ2fjmPKRWQn3_qzw.text: This is a solid restaurant and does well with presenting game meat as the star to many of their dishes.  The service was friendly and efficient.  The pace was a bit hurried n

9rZfpnPFyZER1DjRx3GNrA.text: The Harwood Arms concept was quite fun.  I love a good neighborhood pub, but they turned it up a notch into more modern and upscale food offerings while leaving the relaxed pub atmosphere.  For a started I had the venison scotch egg which was cooked to perfection.  I also had bone marrow with escargot.  For my main course I also ordered  venison.   I've never had venison other than some type of cured or jerky style.  This was cooked, I believe, medium rare and very flavorful.  Although I normally don't visit upscale restaurants Harwood Arms was a great experience.

NlZVqhrfK6pFy3w-tE7eJA.text: This was listed as one of the 50 best restaurants of London by Time Out and they're not wrong.Located in Fulham, this gastro pub has a very nice cosy feeling to it, perfect for dinner with friends, date or even a business dinner. It's a pretty calm/quiet place with tons of space between the tables. They do a set dinner (2 courses for £33, 3 for £39) which includes the best meat I've eaten in a long time (and I don't really like meat). The special of the day comes with mashed potatoes with fried shallots that are almost as good as the one from L'atelier de Joel Robuchon. They have a very long list of wines (although we sticked to beer and cider).Perfect quantities, small enough so you're still hungry for dessert.

photos.caption: Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. NON sugary donuts with rasberry jam and NON sugary vanilla cream
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Harwood Arms - London, United Kingdom. Rack of dear with bone marrow tart

aGIk3X1MS-PX5O94Zoklwg.text: My partner in Michelins and I paid The Harwood Arms a visit for dinner. We lucked out and had no issues snagging a reservation a day or two in advance at London's only pub with a Michelin star. Having survived some Tube problems, it was quite nice to stroll around a pretty residential neighborhood as we tried to find this pub.We were cheerfully welcomed and seated in the bright dining area (lots of windows). Some complimentary wheat bread started off the meal on a positive note. I think we had to pay for the bottle of water though, if I recall correctly. We decided to get the £42.50 three course dinner since that way, we could get dessert, naturally! If you lack a sweet tooth, the two course dinner is £35.50. We made sure to get different dishes so we could sample more things, an excellent strategy.1. Berkshire wood pigeon faggots with celeriac, prune and crispy shallotsI didn't know what to expect, but what I got was meatballs. Very satisfactory. The crispy shallots were my favorite part. Not super prune-y.2. Braised jowl of Tamworth pork with bacon marmalade, cider pickled cabbage and appleMy friend got the lamb and I must've been eyeing it during the whole course. It truly looked splendid, and I relished the morsel I got to sample. But to my relief, there was nothing shameful about ordering the pork. The meat was soft and everything was just darn delicious. The marmalade verged on being too salty but was kept in check. The side of the potatoes was incredibly creamy and smooth. Mmm.3. Warm malted chocolate cake with pearl barley and lovage ice creamAs much as it pains me to say it, the dessert was the weakest pillar of the meal, and I love dessert. The chocolate cake wasn't too sweet but I thought it could be a touch sweeter. The barley added an intriguing squishy bead texture. The lovage ice cream tasted like a blend of celery and licorice, and I'm not the biggest fan of either so it was a miss for me. The ice cream was a stunning mint hue, I'll say.The service was good; both a woman and a man served us. It got maybe a little less attentive towards the end of the meal, but it was fine overall. Lovely bathrooms with pleasant-smelling soap. The Harwood Arms: definitely one of my top meals in London. [Yelp review #400!]

KR9FPuuWKAPsy3RCewrChg.text: Buried in the west side of London, we tried to find a good place to eat near Hammersmith that wouldn't kill our business budget but still give us a fantastic meal.  Thanks to Michelin and the many positive yelp reviews, we decided to come here.  This was possibly one of the best meals we had but also the quirkiest.  The food was truly enjoyable and we wished we ordered the venison roast for two as we saw table after table getting fed this magnificent feast.  Next time I say!So Harwood Arms is tucked aside from the busy streets and I love how it's so quaint and secluded... you're away from the crazy traffic (and it truly was crazy) and you get to enjoy this great gastropub.  The place is quite wonderful with it's many wood finishes, heads of animals decorating the walls, and open windows.  I love how they spaced the tables far from each other so you can still hear your own conversation without yelling.The service is a bit quirky... and slow.  We had a very happy but unusual server and though she clearly tried, it almost felt like she was too strained for a full restaurant and she was a bit dictative on how things should be enjoyed.  Her answers to our menu questions were comically unhelpful but that's because we had the most wonderful server from Angelsea Arms the day before to compare.  Our plates did sit for quite some time between entree and dessert.  Perhaps a full restaurant on a Wednesday was not forecasted and they were short staff?As for the food... oh dear lord.  This is the best meal of the entire trip... lovely plating but the taste matters more and they did bring the flavour out of wonderful ingredients!  We started with the mackeral which was the special of the day.  Normally other restaurants dont handle this well and it can be strong.. in the hands of the Harwood, the skin was crispy like a perfect kettle cooked crisp, the meat was moist still and was complimented wonderfully with the sides and citrus based sauce that cut the fatty meat nicely.  I had the salmon which was perfectly cooked again... they really know how to handle seafood and fish impeccably.  My colleague had the duck and he thought it was the best duck he's had in a long time and possibly all of London. We had a scotch egg to try and wow... best rendition in a long time.  They added venison to the pork encasing a great egg with molten yolk.  Fantastic.  We decided to eat the dessert though we were quite full and I dont regret it. I had the strawberry tart which was like a hit of summer in sugary bite.  My friend wanted lighter and he enjoyed the honey mousse.Aside from the slow and quicky service, this was definitely one of the highlights of our trip.  I'll definitely try coming back as it's only 10 minutes from our office.  Love this place

s2sOZwPEvgX0atx7K4ohSg.text: Let's start by saying that it was great! Even if it's a little far from the center it's totally worth it. The service is perfect, they will be there to answer to any of your request but won't be too present. The place feels cosy, like a good old familial pub should be but with a hint of "poshness". Quiet and with plenty of space. The food was also amazing (Time out Top 50) and I loved almost everything that I tried there.I had the 2 courses set for dinner (£33) with a starter: cornish crab on muffins, as main: a perfectly cooked pheasant with greens and potato and as dessert: donuts with rasberry jam and vanilla cream that was a bit NON sugary for me (booouuuh).It was an overall perfect experience and would gladly go back there to try something else.

waiCZhYkxppB4JRTpFWwUA.text: definitely need more gastropubs like this in nyc.  so glad my friend and i made it a point to visit this place on a tuesday for lunch right before our flight (after failing the day before, not realizing they were closed for monday lunches).  the place is cozy, with a home-feel to the setting.  we decided to be ambitious and try some meats we'd normally never get in the states - berkshire deer and pidgeon dishes- my doubts disappeared the minute i took a bite as all the dishes were prepared brilliantly.i'd definitely visit again the next time i'm in london.

eK15xFQw66z-bXvm55463g.text: With pedigree such as the Pot Kiln in Berkshire and the much-lauded Ledbury in Notting Hill overseeing its re-launch, The Harwood Arms was always destined for great things, becoming the first London pub to achieve a Michelin Star in the 2010 guide. The interiors are simple and rustic, but the distinctly British cooking, including favourites such as venison scotch egg, is at the top of its game

MLQGasfIlYR4gI2QRRSZXQ.text: Outstanding food. Everything is well conceived and delicious. And it goes from strength to strength. The Camp coffee creme is so delicious!

JdleIpuYsMGHz9YucQhzsQ.text: More than just a contender for the best gastropub in London. The locals are very lucky to have this establishment. Regrettably for most mortals, the locals are primarily of the hooray henry horsey variety, but not needlessly uncivil or boorish. Being a gastropub (an unfortunate, but admittedly convenient expression), the Harwood Arms is informal and slightly chaotic, but there is no doubting the brilliance of the food and the sheer audacious inspiration of its menu. In autumn, for example, there is a dominance of game - pheasant, hare, wood pigeon, rabbit, grouse, venison - and year-round you can eat huge Herefordshire snails or delicious Dorset crab or smoked eels. The wine list is refreshingly broad and balanced, and very reasonably priced - such a relief from the constantly abusive mark-ups you get in most other restaurants in Central or West London. This is a damn fine place to eat, no question.

bd2KE5Suc6soiGfzNwsT3g.text: A very cosy pub, one with a decent selection of drinks and food on sale. For a wintery night this pub is ideal for a quiet drink among friends, and is never too busy to be uncomfortable. It isn't the easiest play to find, so make sure you have a map! It is a celeb spot too, I saw Natalie from Eastenders in there, if you remember her!

BD1qxhg0h8QgfN0ipBxgFg.text: The Harwood Arms has a lovely cosy feel to it. Leather sofas by a fire and a worn mish mash of chairs a tables give the place a comfortable familiar feel. The service is always warm and friendly too. The food is pretty good on the whole (although the nachos were a real letdown). They do a chocolate fondant to die for - its so good! All in all a really nice pub for dinner or just a quiet drink

msZYrEbqOyPfkY5Jeg5sWQ.text: This was my first meal in London on my most recent visit.  I was operating on no sleep and had been awake for 30 hours so I immediately was smitten with the cozy atmosphere of the restaurant. We had kind of a bad table in the middle of the room, but this didn't dampen our spirits. I had the delicious scotch egg, a parsnip soup with fried pig's ears and the pan roasted pheasant. It was just the hearty, well-executed food that I need that night. My wife and our friends enjoyed some wine and savored being back in London. This will be a place I make a point of dining at on all future visits.

oIvL--BrkzXTI6JBmCpHug.text: Perfect for a lazy sunday afternoon. Nice sofa and no plasma distractions. Just open up your paper and sip your favourite tipple aaaahhhh.

5fcONSPth5kiw-Q0G61OKg.text: Some of the best food I have had in London. Nice staff and decent prices. Well worth a visit.
